kadot package¶

Submodules¶

kadot.bot_engine module¶

kadot.fuzzy module¶

Inspired by FuzzyWuzzy: https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy

kadot.fuzzy.extract(query: kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, choices: Sequence[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens], best: Union[int, NoneType] = None, ratio_function: Callable[..., float] = <function ratio>) → List[Tuple[str, int]]¶

Find the best most similar choices to the query.

Parameters:
  • query – a Tokens object.
  • choices – a list of Tokens objects.
  • best – the most similar number of choices to return. If None (default), the function will return all choices.
  • ratio_function – a function calculating the similarity between two Tokens objects.
Returns:

a list of tuple containing the plain text of the extracted choice and its similarity with the query.
kadot.fuzzy.ratio(s1: Union[str, kadot.tokenizers.Tokens], s2: Union[str, kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]) → float¶

Compute the similarity ratio between two (tokenized or not) strings.

>>> ratio('I ate the apple', 'I ate the pear')
0.759
kadot.fuzzy.token_ratio(s1: kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, s2: kadot.tokenizers.Tokens) → float¶

Compute the similarity ratio between two tokenized strings.

>>> token_ratio(regex_tokenizer('I ate the apple'), regex_tokenizer('the apple I ate'))
0.5
kadot.fuzzy.vocabulary_ratio(s1: kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, s2: kadot.tokenizers.Tokens) → float¶

Compute the similarity ratio of the vocabulary of two tokenized strings.

>>> vocabulary_ratio(regex_tokenizer('I ate the apple'), regex_tokenizer('the apple I ate'))
1.0

kadot.models module¶

class kadot.models.EntityRecognizer(train: Dict[str, Tuple[str]], tokenizer: Callable[..., kadot.tokenizers.Tokens] = <function regex_tokenizer>, configuration={'embedding_dimension': 20, 'entity_size_range': (1, 11), 'hidden_size': 10, 'iter': 800, 'learning_rate': 0.01, 'mean_ratio': 0.75, 'min_tolerance': 0.0001})¶

Bases: kadot.utils.SavedObject

A text classifier using scikit-learn.

kadot.preprocessing module¶

kadot.preprocessing.summarizer(text: str, lenght: int, separator: str = '. ', vectorizer_config: dict = {'dimension': 300, 'iter': 1000, 'model': {'min_count': 1, 'sg': 1}, 'window': 20}) → str¶

Summarize a text.

Parameters:
  • text – input text to summarize.
  • lenght – length (in number of sentences) of the summary.
  • separator – separator that joins the sentences of the summary together.
  • vectorizer_config – dictionary “kwargs” giving the custom parameters to word2vec_vectorizer.
Returns:

a summary based on excerpts from the original text.
kadot.preprocessing.tfidf(document: kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, corpus: Sequence[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]) → Dict[str, float]¶

Returns the TF-IDF score of words in a given tokenized document based on a given tokenized corpus.

kadot.preprocessing.twitter_preprocess(text: str, no_rt: bool = True, no_mention: bool = False, no_hashtag: bool = False) → str¶

Preprocessing function to remove retweets, mentions and/or hashtags from raw tweets.

>>> twitter_preprocess("RT @the_new_sky: Follow me !")
'Follow me !'
>>> twitter_preprocess("@the_new_sky please stop making ads for your #twitter account.", no_mention=True, no_hashtag=True)
' please stop making ads for your  account.'
kadot.preprocessing.url_preprocess(text: str, exclude: Sequence[str] = ()) → str¶

Preprocessing function to remove some or all URLs from a text.

Parameters:
  • text – input text to preprocess.
  • exclude – a tuple or a list containing the domains to exclude, if empty (default) all URLs will be deleted.
Returns:

the text without URLs.

 
>>> url_preprocess("Check this article : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Python_(programming_language)")
'Check this article : '
>>> url_preprocess("https://www.bing.com/search?q=python or https://www.google.fr/search?q=python", exclude=('www.bing.com'))
' or https://www.google.fr/search?q=python'

kadot.tokenizers module¶

class kadot.tokenizers.Tokens(text: str, tokens: Sequence[str], delimiters: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None, starts_with_token: Union[bool, NoneType] = None, exclude: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None)¶

Bases: kadot.utils.SavedObject

An object representing a tokenized text.

ngrams(n: int) → list¶

Returns n-grams of the text. Based on a code found on locallyoptimal.com

rebuild(tokens: Union[Tokens, Sequence[str]]) → str¶

Allows you to reconstruct a modified raw text using the word delimiters of the original text.

kadot.tokenizers.corpus_tokenizer(corpus: List[str], lower: bool = False, exclude: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None, tokenizer: Callable[..., kadot.tokenizers.Tokens] = <function regex_tokenizer>) → List[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]¶

Tokenize a whole list of documents (corpus) using the same tokenizer.

>>> corpus_tokenizer(['Hello bob !', 'Hi John !'])
[Tokens(['Hello', 'bob']), Tokens(['Hi', 'John'])]
kadot.tokenizers.ngram_tokenizer(text: str, n: int = 2, separator: str = '-', lower: bool = False, exclude: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None, tokenizer: Callable[..., kadot.tokenizers.Tokens] = <function regex_tokenizer>) → kadot.tokenizers.Tokens¶

A “meta” tokenizer that returns n-grams as tokens.

Parameters:
  • text – the text to tokenize.
  • n – the size of the gram.
  • separator – the separator joining words together in a gram.
  • lower – if True, the text will be written in lowercase before it is tokenized.
  • exclude – a list of words and/or gram that should not be included after tokenization.
  • tokenizer – the word tokenizer to use.
Returns:

a Tokens object.

 
>>> ngram_tokenizer("This is another example.")
Tokens(['This-is', 'is-another', 'another-example'])
kadot.tokenizers.regex_tokenizer(text: str, lower: bool = False, exclude: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None, delimiter: Pattern[~AnyStr] = re.compile('[.,!?:;()[\\]{}><+\\-*/\\= "\'\r\t\n\x0b\x0c@^¨`~_|]+')) → kadot.tokenizers.Tokens¶

Tokenize using regular expressions.

Parameters:
  • text – the text to tokenize.
  • lower – if True, the text will be written in lowercase before it is tokenized.
  • exclude – a list of words that should not be included after tokenization.
  • delimiter – the regex defining what delimits words between them.
Returns:

a Tokens object.

 
>>> regex_tokenizer("Let's try this example.")
Tokens(['Let', 's', 'try', 'this', 'example'])
kadot.tokenizers.whitespace_tokenizer(text: str, lower: bool = False, exclude: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None) → kadot.tokenizers.Tokens¶

Tokenize considering that words are separated by whitespaces characters.

Parameters:
  • text – the text to tokenize.
  • lower – if True, the text will be written in lowercase before it is tokenized.
  • exclude – a list of words that should not be included after tokenization.
Returns:

a Tokens object.

 
>>> whitespace_tokenizer("Let's try this example.")
Tokens(["Let's", 'try', 'this', 'example.'])

kadot.vectorizers module¶

class kadot.vectorizers.VectorDict(keys: list, matrix: Union[numpy.ndarray, scipy.sparse.lil.lil_matrix], sparse=False)¶

Bases: kadot.utils.SavedObject

An ordered dict to store vectors associated with their documents.

analogy(from1: Union[str, numpy.ndarray], to1: Union[str, numpy.ndarray], from2: Union[str, numpy.ndarray], best: int = 10, exclude: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None, similarity: Callable[[numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray], float] = <function cosine_similarity>) → List[Tuple[str, float]]¶

Find the words that match the most closely to an analogy. For example: “The man is to the woman what the king is to… the queen.”

doesnt_match(keys: list) → str¶

Search the intruder in a list of keys.

g_items()¶

A generator behaving like the item method but converting sparse matrices into numpy array.

g_values()¶

A generator behaving like the value method but converting sparse matrices into numpy array.

items()¶
keys()¶
most_similar(coordinates: Union[str, numpy.ndarray], best: Union[int, NoneType] = 10, exclude: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None, similarity: Callable[[numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray], float] = <function cosine_similarity>) → List[Tuple[str, float]]¶

Find the best most similar words to `coordinates’.

Parameters:
  • coordinates – a vector (numpy array) or a key of a vector in the dictionary.
  • exclude – a list of words to exclude from the result.
  • similarity – a function calculating the similarity between two vectors.
Returns:

a list of tuples containing the most similar words and their cosine similarities.
values()¶
kadot.vectorizers.centroid_document_vectorizer(corpus: Union[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, Sequence[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]], word_vectors: kadot.vectorizers.VectorDict, sparse=False) → kadot.vectorizers.VectorDict¶

A document vectorizer calculating the centroid of the vectors of the words it contains.

Parameters:
  • corpus – a list of Tokens objects or a Tokens object.
  • word_vectors – a VectorDict object containing the word vectors.
Returns:

a VectorDict object containing the document vectors.
kadot.vectorizers.cosine_similarity(vector1: numpy.ndarray, vector2: numpy.ndarray) → float¶

Calculates the cosine similarity of two vectors.

kadot.vectorizers.count_document_vectorizer(corpus: Union[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, Sequence[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]], vocabulary: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None) → kadot.vectorizers.VectorDict¶

A simple “bag-of-words” document vectorizer that simply counts the number of occurrences of each word in each document.

Parameters:
  • corpus – a list of Tokens objects or a Tokens object.
  • vocabulary – the vocabulary used for vectorization in the form of a word list, or if None (default), the vocabulary would be extracted from the corpus.
Returns:

a VectorDict object containing the document vectors.
kadot.vectorizers.doc2vec_vectorizer(corpus: Union[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, Sequence[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]], dimension: int, window: int = 4, iter: int = 1000, model={'dm': 0, 'min_count': 1}) → kadot.vectorizers.VectorDict¶

A document vectorizer using the Paragraph2Vec algorithm (require Gensim).

Parameters:
  • corpus – a list of Tokens objects or a Tokens object.
  • dimension – the number of dimensions of document vectors.
  • model – parameters to pass to the gensim vectorizer. https://radimrehurek.com/gensim/models/doc2vec.html
Returns:

a VectorDict object containing the document vectors.
kadot.vectorizers.fasttext_vectorizer(corpus: Union[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, Sequence[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]], dimension: int, window: int = 4, iter: int = 1000, model={'min_count': 1, 'sg': 0}) → kadot.vectorizers.VectorDict¶

A word vectorizer using the FastText algorithm (require Gensim).

Parameters:
  • corpus – a list of Tokens objects or a Tokens object.
  • dimension – the number of dimensions of word vectors.
  • model – parameters to pass to the gensim vectorizer. https://radimrehurek.com/gensim/models/fasttext.html
Returns:

a VectorDict object containing the word vectors.
kadot.vectorizers.handle_corpus(corpus: Union[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, Sequence[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]]) → Tuple[List[List[str]], List[str]]¶

Utility function to manage the corpus argument of a vectorizer.

Parameters:corpus – a Tokens object or an iterable object containing Tokens objects.
Returns:a tuple containing the list of tokenized texts (in a list form) and the list of raw texts.
kadot.vectorizers.word2vec_vectorizer(corpus: Union[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, Sequence[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]], dimension: int, window: int = 4, iter: int = 1000, model={'min_count': 1, 'sg': 0}) → kadot.vectorizers.VectorDict¶

A word vectorizer using the word2vec algorithm (require Gensim).

Parameters:
  • corpus – a list of Tokens objects or a Tokens object.
  • dimension – the number of dimensions of word vectors.
  • model – parameters to pass to the gensim vectorizer. https://radimrehurek.com/gensim/models/word2vec.html
Returns:

a VectorDict object containing the word vectors.
kadot.vectorizers.word_vectorizer(corpus: Union[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens, Sequence[kadot.tokenizers.Tokens]], window: int = 4, vocabulary: Union[Sequence[str], NoneType] = None) → kadot.vectorizers.VectorDict¶

A distributional word vectorizer constructing a co-occurrence matrix and applying a dimension reduction algorithm on it.

Parameters:
  • corpus – a list of Tokens objects or a Tokens object.
  • window – the size of a word context window side.
  • vocabulary – the vocabulary used for vectorization in the form of a word list, or if None (default), the vocabulary would be extracted from the corpus.
Returns:

a VectorDict object containing the word vectors.

Module contents¶

Natural language processing using unsupervised vectors representation.
